iii
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 12 Filed 12/31/25 Page 5 of 14
SUMMARY OF ARGUMENT
Proper analysis of the eight Benson factors weighs heavily in favor of
determining that the award to Creditor of half the equity in the marital home was
intended to function as support for Creditor. In re Benson, 441 Fed. App’x at 651.
Under the Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act
(“BAPCPA”), the Bankruptcy Court could have found, as an alternative, that the debt
imposed by the divorce court was non-dischargeable under 11 U.S.C. § 523(a)(15).
1
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 12 Filed 12/31/25 Page 6 of 14
ARGUMENT
I. The Debtor’s analysis of the Benson factors is flawed.
Debtor correctly points out that the Court’s decision in In re Benson, 441 Fed.
App’x 650, 651 (11th Cir. 2011), requires courts to consider eight factors in
determining whether payments from one spouse to another arising from a divorce
decree are domestic support obligations within the meaning of 11 U.S.C. § 101(14A).
However, his analysis of how those factors apply to this case is flawed.
Debtor’s first mistake is his assumption that Creditor contends the payments
ordered by the divorce court are like an award of periodic alimony. But Creditor has
never contended that the payments ordered by the divorce court should be considered
to be like periodic alimony. Creditor’s position has always been that the award to her
“is a debt owed to a former spouse that was incurred as a result of a [separation
agreement, divorce decree, or] property settlement agreement that is ‘in the nature of
alimony, maintenance, or support ... [of that former spouse] without regard to
whether such debt is expressly so designated.’” Benson, 441 Fed.App’x. at 651
(quoting 11 U.S.C. § 101(14A)) (emphasis in original) (bracketed material added).
Then Debtor erroneously jumps to the provisions of Alabama law which
describe events that terminate an award of periodic alimony, such as remarriage,
2
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 12 Filed 12/31/25 Page 7 of 14
cohabitation, or death. Appellee’s Br. at 13 citing Ala. Code § 30-2-55.1 But a debt
owed to a former spouse incurred as a result of a divorce decree can be in the nature
of alimony in gross, maintenance, or support, thus falling within the definition of a
domestic support obligation. 11 U.S.C. § 101(14A)
In Whitehurst v. Whitehurst, ___ So.3d ___, 2024 WL 4395288 (Ala. Civ. App.
Oct. 4, 2024), the Court stated:
Alimony in gross is considered “compensation for the
[recipient spouse’s] inchoate marital rights [and] ... may
also represent a division of the fruits of the marriage where
liquidation of a couple’s jointly owned assets is not
practicable.” Hager v. Hager, 293 Ala. at 54, 299 So. 2d at
749. ... In other words, alimony in gross is a form of
property settlement. Hager v. Hager, 293 Ala. at 54, 299
So. 2d at 749. An alimony-in-gross award is generally not
modifiable. Id.
Id. at *3 (Bracketed material in original).
The law is clear that the determination of whether a debt arising from a divorce
decree is a domestic support obligation which is non-dischargeable under 11 U.S.C.
§ 523(a)(5), does not turn on whether it is alimony or a property settlement. Edwards
v. Colin, 2017 WL 1822570, *2 (M.D. Ala. May 5, 2017). A property settlement can
be a non-dischargeable domestic support obligation. In re Benson, 441 Fed. App’x
1 This statute has been held to apply only to an award of periodic alimony.
Trammell v. Trammell, 523 So.2d 437 (Ala. Civ. App. 1988).
3
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 12 Filed 12/31/25 Page 8 of 14
at 651-52; Cummings v. Cummings, 244 F.3d 1263, 1266-67 (11th Cir. 2001). The
question is whether the property settlement is “in the nature of support.” Id. at 1265.
Turning to the eight Benson factors, the proper analysis follows:
(1) the agreement’s language—there was no agreement in this case so there is no
indicator of the parties’ intent;
(2) the parties’ financial positions when the agreement was made—Debtor’s monthly
income was over five times more than Creditor’s monthly income which favors a
determination that the debt is for Creditor’s support;
(3) the amount of the division—the parties’ equity in the marital residence is equal
to $102,822.42, with the $2,000 monthly payments to Creditor equal to 115% of her
monthly income of $1,733, which favors a determination that the debt is for
Creditor’s support;2
(4) whether the obligation ends upon death or remarriage of the beneficiary—since
the award amounts to half of the parties’ equity in the marital residence, it appears
more like a property settlement, and thus, alimony in gross, which does not terminate
2 Although Debtor is correct in asserting that Creditor will receive 100% of the
debt she is owed as a general unsecured creditor, if her claim is a non-dischargeable,
domestic support obligation, i.e.,a priority claim, Creditor would receive her payment
much sooner. Appellee Br. at 4, ¶ 17.
4
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 12 Filed 12/31/25 Page 9 of 14
upon death or remarriage, which favors a determination that the debt is for Creditor’s
support;3
(5) the frequency and number of payments—the fact that the divorce decree orders
21 monthly payments of $2,000 favors a determination that the debt is for Creditor’s
support;
(6) whether the agreement waives other support rights—the divorce decree provides
that neither party is awarded alimony which favors a determination that the debt is for
Creditor’s support since she receives nothing else from the divorce decree;
(7) whether the obligation can be modified or enforced in state court—a property
settlement such as alimony in gross cannot be modified in state court which favors
a determination that the debt is for Creditor’s support;
(8) how the obligation is treated for tax purposes—Under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act
of 2017, Pub. L. No. 115-97, 131 Stat. 2054 (2017), which repealed 26 U.S.C. § 71
and 26 U.S.C. § 215 (Repealed), alimony payments made pursuant to divorce
judgments entered after December 31, 2018, are no longer taxable income to the
3 Debtor argues that because Creditor remarried, Debtor’s support obligation
terminated. But Debtor again assumes that Creditor’s debt was like periodic alimony,
instead of alimony in gross, which is unaffected by Creditor’s remarriage. Regardless,
Creditor testified that she remarried before the appeal from the judgment of divorce
in her case was decided. R. 22. Under Ala. Code § 30-2-10, her remarriage was not
valid because her judgment of divorce was not final at the time of her remarriage. See
Appellee Br. at 3, ¶ 13.
5
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 12 Filed 12/31/25 Page 10 of 14
recipient nor tax deductible by the payor. Whitehurst v. Whitehurst, ___ So.3d ___,
2024 WL 4395288, at *4 (Ala. Civ. App. Oct. 4, 2024). This factor does not apply.
Thus, proper analysis of the Benson factors weighs heavily in favor of
determining that the award to Creditor of half the equity in the marital home was
intended to function as support for Creditor. In re Benson, 441 Fed. App’x at 651.
II. Changes made by BAPCPA further support finding the
divorce court’s equitable distribution of assets a non-
dischargeable, domestic support obligation.
In 2005, Congress passed the Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer
Protection Act (“BAPCPA”). Debtor candidly admits that he does not understand
Creditor’s argument that 11 U.S.C. § 523(a)(15), one of the changes brought about
by BAPCPA, is an alternative basis upon which this Court can find that the divorce
court’s award to Creditor of half the equity in the marital home is a non-
dischargeable, domestic support obligation. Creditor appreciates Debtor’s candor.
In In re McCollum, 415 B.R. 625 (M.D. Ga. 2009), the Court explained the
difference between non-dischargeability under 11 U.S.C. § 523(a)(5) and under 11
U.S.C. § 523(a)(15). The Court stated:
Subsection (a)(15) applies to debts that do not fall with
[sic] the definition of a domestic support obligation but
were, nevertheless, “incurred by the debtor in the course of
a divorce or separation or in connection with a separation
agreement, divorce decree or other order of a court of
6
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 12 Filed 12/31/25 Page 11 of 14
record[.]” Id. § 523(a)(15). For expediency, debts under §
523(a)(5) are generally referred to as being in the nature of
alimony or support, while debts under § 523(a)(15) are
referred to as being in the nature of property division.
Id. at 629.
Since debts “in the nature of a property division” can be in the nature of
support, they can still be non-dischargeable, domestic support obligations within the
meaning of 11 U.S.C. § 101(14A). In re Benson, 441 Fed. App’x at 651-52;
Cummings v. Cummings, 244 F.3d 1263, 1266-67 (11th Cir. 2001). Thus, the
Bankruptcy Court could have found, alternatively, that the debt was non-
dischargeable under 11 U.S.C. § 523(a)(15).
CONCLUSION
Based on the arguments and authorities cited hereinabove, the Order of the
Bankruptcy Court reclassifying Creditor’s Claim Number 19 as a general unsecured
claim is due to be reversed.
7
Case 3:25-cv-00721-BL Document 12 Filed 12/31/25 Page 12 of 14
Respectfully submitted this 31st day of December, 2025.
/s/ Algert S. Agricola, Jr.
Attorney for Appellant Brittany Michelle
Gilliland
